content:
Nice clash, but it's quite hard to understand how the precedence of the sorting works in-clash from just your statement.

I'd change:
"Characters case does matter in sorting : words with first letter uppercase will appear after lowercase words ("Hello" after "hello")." to
"Characters case does matter in sorting : words with first letter uppercase will appear after lowercase words that are otherwise the same ("Hello" after "hello")."

Otherwise it sounds like you mean that all capitalised words should come after all words thata aren't.

I'd similarly change the Output line to:
"the [[words]] string sorted by length and alphabetically for words of same length, with capitalised words sorted after their uncapitalised versions."

I'd also add a constraint that:
"Uppercase characters will only ever appear at the start of a word"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear objective: The goal of the challenge is well-defined. Participants need to sort the given string of words by their length and alphabetically (ascending order) for words of the same length. The character case matters in the sorting.

Input and Output: The input and output format is clearly described, with examples provided to help participants understand what is expected.

Constraints: The constraints on the number of words in the string, as well as the word length, are provided, ensuring the problem remains solvable and within reasonable bounds.

Example: The provided example helps participants understand the expected output format and how the sorting should be performed.

Overall, the challenge is well-structured, and the requirements are well-defined, making it suitable for publication.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like your idea you have used here. Also all statements seem to be clear best of luck.

Good clash!

Just one recommendation: Move the "character case matters" test case and validator up a bit and maybe add another one. This is mainly for reverse players as some might submit after a few test cases pass and then not get 100%.

Goal section
* Please mention whether the sorting needs to take into account of letter case.

Constraints section
* Please mention that all words in [[words]] contain alphabetical characters only.

Cases
* The first test violates the second constraint as some words are of length 2 or 3 only.

* "Colors" (validator) and "Lots of words" (test) violate the second constraint as some words are of length 3 only.

* I would suggest to add some tests where letter case matters. (By the way, I notice that no words begin with an uppercase letter in the validators.)

Thanks.
Nice one ! Maybe you should specify if characters case matters in sorting or not.
Thanks for your comment. I'm adding your suggestions !

An example in the statement could really help.

"The dog that the man named Dog"
->
"dog Dog man the The that named"

Thank you!

Just one point about the newly added test: there is a word "Circus-Circus" which contains a non-alphabetical character. That violates the 3rd constraint. Suggest to remove the word.
